column4: noob question, when compiling a new kernel is it possible to have the make config script search lspci and only select the modules it detects?  it such a pain in the posterior to have to make a new config for each kernel version
you can use the previous kernel config file as a starting point for the new kernel.
really? i'm surprized more people haven't asked that.
it would seem to make the process a little more effecient.  but, maybe that's just me
I wonder what the negative aspect of having the make script search for installed compents would be.
there has to be some reason they haven't implemented it
lots of folks like to throw in modules for devices they don't yet have. people who care enough to build their own kernels take the time to do it right.
you can use the previous kernel config as a starting point for the new kernel config, so that you only need to review new/changed modules.
I know this isn't the right place to ask, but has anybody ever experienced a bug with filezilla that only allows 100Mbps transfers over sftp?
and no, I can hit a full 1Gbps over nfs/afp/scp
so if scp can transfer @ 1Gbps it's illogical to assume that the problem lies in cpu or protocol overhead
motd, nfs, scp,afp all transfer at 100Mbyte+
that's what I'm thinking but I can't find anything about it

it's also a very curious bug.  If I open  10 conncurrent transfer then I can reach ~100MBps just like over scp or nfs.  but each individual connection through filezila never transfer at a higher rate than 100Mbit/s
have you tried the filezilla forum? contacting the developers? filing a bug report?
